captions.text:
In our everyday world, we're used to absolute,
deterministic predictions: throw a ball in

the air, and it'll fall along an ellipse;
leave your umbrella parked on the street,

and when you come back, it's still there,
just one umbrella.

Quantum physics is not like this - because
quantum mechanics doesn't allow us to make

absolute predictions about the future. It
only predicts the likelihoods of different

outcomes to happen, and doesn't say anything
about which one will happen. "Well," you might

say, "that's the same with the weather - the
weatherman only tells you what the chance

of rain is; he can't tell you whether or not
it will rain."

But maybe the weatherman just doesn't have
good enough knowledge of exactly where all

of the air and water molecules in the world
are, nor a good enough model of how they interact

or a fast enough computer to simulate all
of their bajillion interactions. Maybe in

principle, if he had enough data and a fast
enough computer, his weather model could tell

you exactly where every raindrop would fall.
Right? This reasonable idea, that if you just

had more data you could explain everything,
is the classical, deterministic view of the
universe.

And for a while, many physicists, including
Einstein, thought the same had to be true

with quantum mechanics - maybe we just didn't
have enough information to put into our quantum

models; maybe there were classical variables
that were hidden from us and our experiments,

inputs that explained everything perfectly
with no need for quantum mechanics and its

"I'll give you 50/50 odds on the cat being
dead" mentality.

Except, it turns out that we can actually
test whether or not this sort of classical,

underlying explanation of quantum physics
can exist even in principle. The details are

a topic for another video, but the experiments
tell us… there is no classical, everyday,
underlying description of quantum mechanics.

And this means, Einstein, that the universe
is quantum mechanical whether you like it
with a 50% chance, or not.

ps, I'm excited to announce that MinutePhysics
is now supported by MinutePhysics t-shirts.

Get yours now at dftba.com/minutephysics and
don't forget to be awesome.

comments.author: E8oL4

comments.text:
not classical mechanics, the thing i call false is the view, that we could 
theoretically compute every position of every particle at any given point 
of time if we knew where it was before and where it was headed and thus 
foretell the future (the classical deterministic view, not classical 
mechanics).
comments.author: E8oL4

comments.text:
+E8oL4 Classical mechanics is not "false." Classical mechanics refers to 
phenomena in a constant time frame and within sizes smaller than planets 
and larger than atoms. The theories of the very large do not apply to the 
very small. Thus, the theories of the very small are not very good at 
explaining the very large. Classical mechanics is "correct."

comments.text:
I don't know anything about quantum mechanics, so I'm not really the guy to 
discuss this. And I think that what you just said is the overall point of 
the video; the problem is, he hadn't yet explained the probabilistic nature 
of quantum mechanics, so stating that it was a chaotic system was 
irrelevant at that point, since chaotic systems are, by definition, 
deterministic.
comments.author: Guilherme Pata

comments.text:
+Guilherme Pata Except every interaction has an underlying quantum 
mechanical nature. Sure the world may be 99.999% deterministic in the macro 
environment (the Plank constant is small) but the quantum uncertainty 
affects every system.

Whether an electron goes spin up or spin down IS like a Butterfly that can 
cause change in the future like a Butterfly flapping its wings causing a 
hurricane. Little quantum uncertainties will add up drastically overtime 
making the future indeterminate. 


The world is a complex, chaotic, and probabilistic.
comments.author: dutchrjen

comments.text:
Exactly, I didn't really get why he wrote that comment. The problem with 
chaotic systems is that small variations will change the outcome 
drastically... But if the weather man *did* know the position of every 
molecule (which sounds pretty impossible) and had a physical model that 
could perfectly explain their interactions with other molecules, and a 
computer to do those calculations, he could, in principle, predict the 
weather with 100% accuracy.

I am a believer in the classical deterministic world view. But a few years

Now my question is, does the non-deterministic behaviour of the quantum

comments.author: thegreeenbeast

comments.text:
+WaterMelonFan1 No, the Butterfly Effect disproves that idea. Even the 
smallest bit of probability adds up overtime. In principle it may be 
possible to accurately predict what will happen in the next 30 seconds for 
example to a reasonable level for some things but the next 300 years will 
be much less deterministic.

The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principles all derive from the following two 
fundamental relations:


del E * del t >or= hbar/2


del x * del p >or= hbar/2


Where del is change in (uncertainty), E =energy, t= time, x = position, and 
p = momentum


At anyone point you can know everything about energy precisely but know 
nothing about time or you can know momentum precisely but know nothing 
about position. That is there could be 100% uncertainty in a variable. 
Really because "particles" are made out of wave packets there isn't 
anything more to "know" about the particle. I don't even like the word 
uncertainty because it's not that we don't know where the particle is its 
that the particle itself is spread out. No one really disputes this. The 
key unknown is how the wave-packet chooses to localize when something 
interacts with it. How does it decide to localize in one spot over another 
when observed? Bell's inequality seems to show that it is random. 


Many everyday events like reflections off of glass have a high level of 
uncertainty. Will the photon tunnel through or won't it? That's a macro 
quantum effect. This randomness does add up overtime. For example quantum 
errors add up quite fast in modern computers making it necessary for there 
to be data checks and redundancy. Modern solid-state physics and computer 
science needs to be fully aware of quantum errors or programs wouldn't 
function. That is errors would accrue so fast computers wouldn't function. 
If we can't even use and predict computer code without errors how the hell 
can we predict the future? What about the random errors in DNA caused by 
such things as radiation? Little mutations lead to evolution (or cancer) 
which lead to huge amounts of change.
comments.author: dutchrjen

comments.text:
Determinism is allowed by quantum mechanics, as long as you're willing to 
give up locality.
comments.author: AlphaetusPrime

comments.text: That does put a major dent in the classical deterministic theory

comments.author: WaterMelonFan1

comments.text:
That is true. But the decay of unstable particles is quite a major part of 
the working of the universe if you spread out its effect over billions of 
years. So although the deterministic view works over shorter periods of 
time, or even over a lifetime, it isnt true that our daily lifes and the 
small events we encounter throughout the day were already predetermined at 
the dawn of time.
comments.author: thegreeenbeast

comments.text:
Actually, there are a few effects of QM that influence our daily life, for 
example the nuclear fusion in our sun oder alpha-decay of radioactive 
materials. These are only possible due to quantum properties of particles. 
You can't predict when two protons merge, or when uranium decays, these are 
totally random processes (really, you can't do anything to influence them). 
You can only calculate a probability for those things to happen (because in 
a sun there are gigantic numbers of particles there is always some fusion 
there and it won't stop shining, same for radioactive decay in the core of 
the earth). So in some cases a deterministic world view is not enough to 
explain our nature, but in most (nearly all) daily life processes i would 
still support such a world view. If i drive against a tree with a high 
speed, i will die. That is in the context of our daily life, a absolute 
truth, even if there are some uncertainties i do not know. Too much 
thinking about the uncertainty of my final position after the crash won't 
help and is just unimportant.
comments.author: WaterMelonFan1

comments.text:
I suspected as much, but not even when stretched over billions of years of 
time? Because determinism basically said everything that happens now was 
already a certainty when the universe came into existence. I tend to agree 
with your statement but i want to be sure before i let it affect my 
philosophical world view.
comments.author: thegreeenbeast

comments.text:
Not really. Because plancks constant (the defining factor when calculating 
uncertainty) is extremely small, there are no measurable effects from QM in 
our daily life. So even though you can't predict everything in the 
macroworld exactly, the uncertainty is so small that it would never 
actually effect anything. E.g., it makes no difference if you score a goal 
in football if the ball is 0.00000000000000000000000000001 metres more on 
the left side or on the right.

comments.text:
This is a belief I have held for years that I thought of one day: there is 
no such thing as randomness or chance.  It was when I was watching a movie 
where there were alternate dimensions where in each there was one small 
difference of chance, and I thought "hang on, how could t possibly be 
different?  The interactions between all of the tiny little particles would 
be the same, all the friction and physics would be identical, so the 
outcome must be the same."  I'm so happy I found this video, I've been 
looking through your videos for so long looking for something like this, 
this topic I believe was touched on briefly about a year ago on VSauce's 
channel.﻿

comments.author: Anonymous71475

comments.text:
This is actually one thing I would deem as entirely untrue. I believe 
quantum mechanics can be fully predicted mathematically, in case we had 
more data. This data however is very difficult to dig out.

Why so? Well, every logical explanation I tried to find for quantum 
mechanics lead me to one conclusion: Time is the 4th dimension, and time 
lines are the 5th dimension. This 5th dimension contains countless "stacks" 
of the 4th, and basically everything that "could have been". I'm convinced 
that quantum physics are in fact low mass particles changing timelines in 
perspective to us, and we basically see them leap between multiple 
probability based existences.

If we knew the number of parallel time lines an electron exists in, and how 
its mass causes it to jump between the nearest probabilities in relation to 
us, we could predict how many times that electron would leap and between 
which states. Sadly, a *very* good mathematician with an understanding of 
higher-dimension geometry (eg: tesseracts) needs to try looking at this 
approach.﻿
comments.author: MirceaKitsune

comments.text:
+Matti Kauppinen QM is a probabilistic model that *tries* to explain 
natural phenomenons in a simple way. But the very nature of the model 
itself is incompatible with the determinism we're trying to reach. So you 
are right when you say that QM cannot predict stuff with 100% certainty. If 
we want (and really need) that level of certainty, we either create a new 
model OR enhance the classical model with new knowledge.
comments.author: prog '

comments.text:
+Matti Kauppinen My intuition is that if we could see the universe from a 
multidimensional perspective, we could predict all effects of quantum 
mechanics. We likely can't right now because the factors influencing when a 
particle will leap between different states / existences are way beyond our 
grasp.

It's like the weather I think: Some people in ancient times would have 
stated that weather can certainly not be predicted, and that storms or 
clear skies will happen based on a random event (or when a god wants it 
to). But once modern technology understood all factors involved, everyone 
realized that weather is the product of exact circumstances, and 
understanding those circumstances would predict it.

In this case, each particle might be building a charge in a higher 
dimension, and releasing that charge by "leaping" or "tunneling". We can't 
see what happens beyond time itself, and god knows what sort of physics are 
going on there that no one will ever live to be able to observe. I might be 
entirely wrong of course, but just a thought.
comments.author: MirceaKitsune

comments.text:
Google "many worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics" (im sure i spelled 
that wrong), and you find a consistent mathematical theory quite like 
yours. But no, you cant predict, even with all the data in the world how 
the quantum system will evolve, that is one of the most accepted basic 
principles in QM
comments.author: Matti Kauppinen

comments.text:
+thenomaic Dont be discouraged. If you ever do come to study quantum 
physics at a university level, you see that its actually a *simplification* 
of the laws of physics. Sure some of the laws get more complicated, but the 
unified nature of quantum theory is so beautiful is deserves to be a wonder 
of the world. It's elegance is hidden behind our common sense notions of 
what should be, but once you get beyond that the universe seems to make 
much more sense than it ever did before. So don't be discouraged by the 
"randomness", be encouraged by the fact that it really doesn't make sense 
any other way.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.text:
+Anthony Khodanian Thank you for your detailed answer, i guess i just had a 
hard time with the meaning of "random outcomes"

It's still frustrating though, the more we know about the universe and its 
laws the more complicated it becomes
comments.author: thenomaic

comments.text:
+thenomaic You realize that Quantum mechanics and Relativity are both over 
a hundred years old right? Doubting quantum is like doubting relativity. A 
huge misunderstanding that people have is that Einstein proved newton 
wrong. That is not the case at all. If anything, Einstein ADDED to Newton's 
theory, not subtracted. He showed that newton's laws were what was 
converged to as velocity approached 0. Newton's laws are still a very much 
accurate approximation and used daily. Saying Einstein proved newton wrong 
is like saying Euler proved Aristotle wrong by saying Pi is 3.141592654... 
instead of 3.14... 

Its a common misconception that scientists are proven wrong all the time. 
What DOES happen in science, is that people make an educated guess, that 
guess becomes popular, than decades later when we have the technology to 
perform the experiments, we find out that guess was wrong. That happens all 
the time. What doesn't happen is once we find something to be true from 
experiments and observations, decades later a smart person comes and proves 
they were all wrong. Quantum physics, like atomic theory, continental 
drift, and the round earth theory, has been tested and is no longer an 
educational guess. It will not be disproven in the same way future 
scientists will never show that the earth is in fact not round, but cubical.

And the most infuriating thing of all, we DO know why things in QM are 
random! It's not just an excuse because we dont know why things are random, 
but we have very precise formulas and models and experiments that show why 
these things are random.  Random doesnt mean causeless, it means that the 
outcomes do not form a regular, repeatable pattern. We know this is the 
case from countless experiments, and its silly to think that it will 
somehow change in the future.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.text:
+Anthony Khodanian  Your point is very true, our actual understanding is 
the best we came for now so its the most logical one.

But can you not see the big irony in your statement ? Even the things that 
every and each scientist of the past believed to be true were 
scientifically inaccurate at the end. Hell, Isaac Newton himself was wrong 
in so many ways ( yet it was necassary for physics to advance and come with 
new understanding of our universe and its laws )

Just 3 generations ago people didn't even know about the relativity. Is it 
truly so hard to imagine that what we believe to be the "truth" now is 
actually just wrong. I understand the quantum experiments and why we say 
its random, it is because every experiment we do shows us that its random, 
but maybe in 40-50 years there will come a genius like Einstein with a 
completely new and revolutionary theory and we will understand that quantum 
mechanics are not random at all. It literally happened all the time in the 
history.

Saying that something is random jsut because we do not fully understand " 
why it is random " is just a poor excuse in my opinion,quantum mechanics is 
very new in science many things you now believe to be true, will not be in 
the future.
comments.author: thenomaic

comments.text:
+MirceaKitsune No, we HAVE looked at it multi-dimensionally, and have 
researched more alternative theories than you probably thought existed, and 
after over a century of looking, we have determined with REMARKABLE 
accuracy, that the Quantum Field Theory we have to date is accurate. 
Scientists in the future will never think otherwise, just like they will 
still believe the world is round for as long as there's science. The only 
thing up for debate is how we *interpret* the model we have now.

 Scientists are not refusing to look at anything that might prove the model 
wrong. We HAVE looked, and determined that the model we have now is the 
most accurate. We didnt start with this model, we ended with it.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.text:
+khor khorlius I think that's very correct. I don't claim my theory is the 
absolute right one without more proof... but I do hate how some science 
people take comfort in a model and refuse to look at anything that might 
prove it wrong. In this case many concluded that quantum physics is random 
and that's it... without considering how complex this universe is, how 
particles might work multi-dimensionally, etc. I'm quite sure it's not 
random myself, and once science eventually discovers that they're going to 
be like "Damn... if we bothered to look earlier we could have known this 
years ago".
comments.author: MirceaKitsune

comments.text:
I also believe that quantum mechanics can be fully predicted in some way, 
how i dont know. But I get really frustrated when men of science says 
things like "well it is unpredictable, we have looked and we found nothing 
so therefore it is random" If you gave a person a dice at the middle ages a 
dice he would claim that it would be random, today we know that with enough 
data we can predict that roll of the dice, but we are stunned when a 
problem like this erupt. I like the drawing in this video and how we found 
nothing when we looked for a machinery under the quantum mechanics. what if 
there is a really small machine just slighty above were we have looked or 
if the pipe going down is really small or located in a different place? 
Just because we dont can predict something or on the other hand we can 
predict something says nothing about if the world is determenistic or not. 
I think thats a very philosofical question and to direct find an answer to 
it leis long into the future. what do you think, please respond especially 
if you think im wrong ^^
comments.author: khor khorlius

comments.text:
This kinda disproves itself. If there's a dimension with timelines that 
contain everything that could have been and everything can be predicted if 
you have all the data, that would mean, that there would need to be a 
infinite stack of big bangs that all *have happened* (one for everything 
that could have happened, which is a growing number, thus countable 
infinity). And infinite big bangs that all have happened in their own 
timeline would mean infinite timelines in a dimension of timelines that all 
have their own 4 dimensions, that all *existed all the time*. And that's 
not really a useful hypothesis
comments.author: JaytleBee von Miraus

comments.text:

nor do you have a consistent mathematical model, so there is no reason to 
believe your theory over ones that do.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.text:
+Anthony Khodanian I agree... the universe just works in a certain way, and 
it's up to people to figure out why and how. Everyone figures it out using 
their own approach and studies however. Mine currently lead to the 
conclusion that higher dimensions are involved in creating the 3D world we 
see as space and the 4D world we perceive as the flow of time, and must 
store extra information in complex patterns per particle / quark. Of course 
I can be wrong, but I'd be really surprised if that's entirely incorrect at 
this stage.
comments.author: MirceaKitsune

comments.text:
The great thing about the universe is that it doesn't care about what you 
believe or how uncomfortable you are with how it works. I used to think 
Quantum Physics could be explained classically too. After having studying 
it I now realize that the universe just doesn't make any sense if that were 
true, and that the universe has to be quantized.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.author: luaudesigndf

comments.text:
What about Pilot Wave Theory or at least, similar theories? From what I've 
gathered, those experiments that supposedly disprove the idea of a 
classical universe don't actually show that the universe is not classical, 
but rather that the hidden variables we would need to access in order to 
predict it classically are unobtainable due to quantum effects like the 
uncertainty principle.

In other words, there are hidden variables; it's just impossible to measure 
them.﻿
comments.author: InnovumTechnology

comments.text:
I want to agree with the Therm6000, who suggested that there must be an 
undiscovered basis about the randomness behind quantum uncertainty. I 
believe in an "explainable" universe. But on the other side, I'm also 
familiar with the idea of that every theory about the universe is correct 
until they fail to work so (this is rather a philosophical interpretation 
of the subject). Latter idea means basically that e.g. equations explaining 
the free fall of an object work until the time the object rises instead of 
falling under the effect of gravity (which seems to be highly impossible, 
but no one can suggest that it will NEVER happen, since no one lived until 
the eternity to prove it so).

Comparing these two, all you can say is, whatever we observe is true. This 
is the one and only axiom in science in my opinion (because if we start the 
idea of questioning whether our observations are true or not, things start 
to get very complicated). Other than that, every outcome resulting from the 
observations (assumed to be true) are just predictions on the modelling of 
the system behind the universe. With better observations we have better 
models, which eventually disproving the previous models.

For example, during the days, in which people believed the earth was flat, 
probably it was never argued for some time (either 10 years or hundreds of 
years). And everybody who heard about the theorem thought world is flat and 
not in another shape, UNTIL some people came up with better observations 
and eventually disproved the idea (which was the reality for people). So by 
that logic, no one can suggest that earth will ALWAYS have the shape of a 
planet until the eternity (excluding the possibility of something 
disastrous that can change its shape happening). That means, one day 
astronauts on ISS may wake up and see the earth is flat...﻿

algorithm that uses the system clock in it's equation to provide a number 
that, by normal standards, is completely random, because it utilizes the 
uncertainty of WHEN the random number will be called for. Two identical 
systems that call random numbers at the exact same level at the exact same 
time will produce the exact same number, every time.

comments.text:
No, you don't understand. This is a common misconception about quantum 
physics, that "It is only because we don't have enough technology or data". 
But the point in quantum physics is to treat things as probabilities and 
distributions, rather than point particles. It is in fact more applicable 
for the universe than classical physics. It is an intrinsic limitation of 
human observation, not anything to do with pure information. The fact is 
time and space can't be split down to a single point to isolate something ~ 
essentially, for us. It is like dealing with the resolution of the universe.

comments.author: The Venus Project France

comments.text:
Quantum mechanics is in principle compatible with a deterministic world 
view as well, according to the De Broglie-Bohm theory for one.

The Bell theorem only says that a theory compatible with quantum mechanical 
results must violate either locality or realism. Basically, locality means 
that information cannot travel faster than light and realism means that 
measurement results are predetermined in some way (by 'hidden variables') 
rather than being randomly generated when you do the measurement.

The Bohm theory suggests that a sort of wave function emanates infinitely 
and instantaneously from all particles and by interference determines 
trajectories and states, preserving realism but sacrificing locality. For 
simple cases at least (double-slit experiment e.g.) the theory has been 
proven to curiously replicate established quantum mechanical results 
exactly.

The theory gets somewhat mathematically clunky (though ultimately free of 
contradiction as far as I know) in comparison with the much more widespread 
Copenhagen interpretation though. It gets more complicated than I care to 
research when you have to deal with instantaneous wave function propagation 
in contrast with the lack of absolute simultaneity in relativity. A 
foliation of space-time supposedly can fix that, but wikipedia can tell you 
more about that than I know :)﻿

comments.author: Graham Davies

comments.text:
This whole video leaves out that even though there is no mathematical model 
for quantum determinism, the future or every quantum state already exists, 
since the past present and future all exist on equal footing, and what is 
perceived as the flow of time is an illusion. So, the only way we could 
predict quantum states would be to somehow see through time on the quantum 
level. This may not be as difficult as we think, since we have already 
conducted experiments that have created small time dilations, such as the 
airplane clock experiment, so all we need is to observe the quantum states 
of particles before we put one of them on an airplane, and then dilate time 
for one of them so that one particle is in the future in relation to the 
other one. Then we just observe the future particle, and see if the past 
particle will behave in its future the way the future particle has already 
behaved.﻿
comments.author: Ben Crispe

comments.text:
The problem with your idea is that you are referring to the airplane clock 
experiment. The experiment had two clocks, and therefore two quantum 
entities with two completely different outcomes. They both had their own 
set quantum states in the future, and they might be verrry close to doing 
the same thing, but not quite. Another problem is you are referring to 
clocks, and clocks are all designed to do the same thing: show you the 
current time. The outcome of 1 clock is pretty much exactly the same as the 
other, as long as they were both the same speed and the time set was the 
same.You are correct in saying that the future has somewhat already 
happened and is fixed, though. Even if I was to go back in time and prevent 
something from happening, I would have still had to move FORWARD in time to 
be able to travel BACK and change that event, meaning me doing that had 
already happened in the future.

comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Samuel Harold
Randomness is as baseless as randomly doing magic and flying: it even *makes 
it possible*! So now I ask you, *why suspect that people could randomly fly 
for no reason*? The argument works both ways: why speculate that 
*randomness* is true when you can't prove it? And if an argument works on 
both sides, it doesn't work at all.

I have to believe one or the other, and even the 'likelihood' *itself* is 
unknown, even with all the things we think we know.

In my head, my logic is as strong as your non-irrefutable proof, therefore 
it is perfectly reasonable for me and others to believe in determinism, and 
it's also impossible to change that opinion or prove me wrong, because of 
the nature of a non-logical world: nothing is provable.

The thing about randomness is that it makes *everything* that ever happens 
a 'what if' hypothesis with nothing to back it up (that's the very point of 
it), even randomness itself, making it unprovable. Only determinism has the 
potential to be irrefutably provable. That's one of the reasons I believe 
in it.

The other reason is that whether you'd ever be happy or not being based on 
dumb luck would just be unfair.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 How do you know that I cant fly when no ones looking? You cant 
no for certain whether I do or don't, you have to loom at the likelihood. 
There is no reason to suspect that I can fly when no one is looking so why 
speculate that I do? You seem to do just that with quantum mechanics. If it 
could somehow be given credit that even quantum has determinism than it 
would be worth acknowledging but as of now its just a 'what if' hypothesis 
that doesn't have anything to back it up.
comments.author: Samuel Harold

comments.text:
+electrocat1 How do you know that that's randomness rather than 
uncertainty? Remember the difference between it being truly *baseless* 
(random) and it being *unknowable* (uncertain).
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 when an electron absorbs a photon, it will reemit it at a random 
time. this is random, there is no pattern that an electron follows for the 
time it takes to reemit a photon.
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
+electrocat1
Okay, so it isn't our own ignorance. It is *everything's* ignorance. It 
can't be known, ever, as you say, but that is uncertainty, not *actual* 
randomness. They're still two different things.

That it's impossible to find both out at the same time in and of itself 
does not mean it isn't deterministic. You can't definitely SAY or KNOW 
anything, but that's not the definition of determinism.

+Samuel Harold
Randomness is baseless by definition, just because of what it is. Because 
it literally *has no base*. That means that, were randomness to be true, 
that would mean that the world is fundamentally not based on logic.

And since the world is random, it would be impossible to ever make 
irrefutable logical claims about anything. Because fundamental logic does 
not exist at all.

And therefore, it is literally impossible to prove randomness beyond a 
shadow of a doubt, whether it's true or not. Determinism *can* be *proven* 
if it's *true*, but *can't* be *disproved* if it's *false*.

As a result of that *logic*, it is completely impossible to ever change my 
mind. It's impossible to prove me wrong even if I *am* wrong.

So what's my incentive for having this opinion? First, it's the only one 
that could potentially be proven, putting me in a strong position. Second, 
I want to forever maintain the hope that whether you'll ever be happy or 
not is not going to be down to dumb luck, which would be unfair.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 no, it is not our own ignorance. The position and momentum can 
not be known to any observer in the entire universe. An observer could be 
anything, even something like a photon. And elementary particles also 
behave like waves, so there isn't a can't a single position that you can 
definitively say they are in.
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
+Therm6000 But how do you know things cant cause themselves to occur on the 
quantum level? Surely your idea that a -> b -> c is based solely on the

If you've addressed this I didn't see it in that long chain. I too wouldn't 
be surprised if given more information it turned out that Quantum mechanics 
or nuclear decay was deterministic but being how such knowledge currently 
isn't known I have to go by what is and what is implies a probabilistic 
reality, at least on the quantum level.

I do see any form of logic that would mean that something MUST have a cause

wasn't so. But I don't see how that means that it has to be true for

Basically, it's impossible.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 Of course you are entitled to an opinion but are you not 
starting with a conclusion and trying to work out evidence for that 
conclusion afterwards? Your conclusion being 'everything has a cause'. What 
would it take to change your mind?
comments.author: Samuel Harold

comments.text:
+electrocat1
Look, you know what the uncertainty principle tells us? It tells us that we 
can't KNOW the postion and the momentum of a particle at the same time. We 
can't be *certain* about both at the same time.

But that is not to say they are *actually* random. There's a difference 
between randomness and uncertainty. One is just our own ignorance, the 
other is truly random. In reality, both are determined at the same time, we 
just can't discover both.

+Elias Reiniat You were quick to say that 'I won't listen to reason'. As if 
what I'm saying isn't reasonable and what he's saying is. But that 
statement is biased by your own opinion, not truth, as this is a proper 
discussion.

Not to mention, it is a 100% empty argument, as I could potentially say the 
same about the both of you if I wanted. Equal possible arguments on 
opposite sides always cancel each other out.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text: +electrocat1 Leave it man, he aint listening no reasons.
comments.author: Elias Reiniat

comments.text: I did give "irrefutable" proof. The damn uncertainty principle.
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
+electrocat1 What I'm saying is true; there is NO irrefutable proof of 
quantum mechanics. Not every gap has been filled, and your rebuttal was 
empty, so it's obviously incapable of changing anyone's mind. It contained 
nothing but 'you're wrong'. A good rebuttal should contain 'you're wrong' 
followed by *an actual reason* instead of what you wrote.

Why don't you come up with a non-empty rebuttal BEFORE you tell me that I 
am wrong about this? And don't forget to consider the fact that Bell's 
theorem *only* proves that *local* variables can never explain quantum 
mechanics, and says nothing about *non-local* variables.

And I thought we had already established that my profile picture is 
unrelated to this issue, and that it's not my problem if you can't take me 
seriously just because of my picture. Deal with it. If you still have a 
problem, just *don't mention it*.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
No. You're not. Please actually learn quantum mechanics before you try to 
argue that it's wrong. And I'll say it again, it is extremely hard to take 
you seriously with that profile picture.
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
+electrocat1
Like I said, only the possibility of *local* variables determining quantum 
mechanics has been irrefutably disproven. However, *non-local* variables 
determining quantum mechanics have *not* been disproven. This creates a gap.

Bell's theorem states this: "No physical theory of local hidden variables 
can ever reproduce all of the predictions of quantum mechanics." This 
stipulates *only* local variables, and thusly isn't airtight proof the 
universe is random.

This means that quantum mechanics overall have not been irrefutably proven, 
which means that every opinion is rational, given the fact that the person 
in question is accounting for everything. And I am.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 Yes! There is! Heisenberg's uncertainty principle was published 
in the 1920's! The uncertainty is irrefutable!
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
+im2810 But it hasn't been irrefutably proven yet. There is a gap. 
Deterministic non-local variables have not been proven wrong. So all 
opinions are allowed and no opinions are irrational.

My opinion does not contradict anything, as there is no absolutely 
irrefutable proof of quantum mechanics being random.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000
It's not an opinion. Scientists have proven that the uncertainty of quantum 
mechanics is true. Your "opinion" that quantum mechanics must be 
deterministic actually does contradict many facts established by modern 
science.
comments.author: im2810

comments.text:
+im2810
Well, there's still a gap in the whole thing; deterministic non-local 
variables have not been proven wrong. So you don't *know* that it's true, 
it just seems *likely* to you.

But it's still just an opinion, even if you don't want it to be. All 
opinions are allowed so long as they aren't contradicting any facts.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000

"Particles DO exist before they are observed and it IS deterministic, but 
it's impossible to prove that without observing them. THAT'S the real 
truth."

Like the other commenter said you obviously don't know how the science 
behind this works. As electrocat said, particles exist in waves of 
probability. They genuinely do not exist in a fixed position before they 
are observed. This doesn't make logical sense to our human brains that are 
used to deterministic cause and effect, but we know that it's true.

comments.text:
+adouleadoule Yes. For the purpose of this conversation, think of atoms as 
coins being thrown. If you only have one coin (atom), you have no idea 
whether the outcome will be heads or tails. However, if you have 100 coins, 
you can say that, give or take, 50 will be heads and 50 will be tails. The 
more coins you have, the better predictions will be. And in the macroscopic 
world, objects have moles of atoms, for example a glass of water has about 
10 moles of water molecules. And for you to understand just how big a mole 
is, if you were to evenly cover the entire US surface with 1 mole of rice 
grains, you'd have a pile of rice about 2 km tall (over a mile).
comments.author: 3snoW

comments.text:
Depends on what you mean by "everything". Macroscopic measurements, sure. 
Quantum mechanical measurements, not so much.
comments.author: Narcissist86

comments.text:
So i can more or less foretell everything that will happen in the universe 
but for one specific atom i'm screwed, that's it ?
comments.author: adouleadoule

comments.text:
+adouleadoule Given a large enough population, you can use expected values 
as a prediction of outcome. So quantum mechanical behaviour will 
approximate classical solutions.

For example, whether a singular radioactive atom decays in a given time is 
entirely probabilistic - you simply can't say for certain when the atom 
will decay. However, given a large population, you can accurately predict 
properties such as half-life.
comments.author: Narcissist86

comments.text: +Narcissist86 But i can predict the behavior of my transitors, can't I ?
comments.author: adouleadoule

comments.text:
Quantum mechanics most definitely affect "macro-objects". Phenomena such as 
the colour of many metals and organic compounds, or permanent magnets, or 
the fusion reaction of the sun, or MRI's, or the transistors in your 
computer, all depend on quantum mechanical properties.
comments.author: Narcissist86

comments.author: Tyrone Biggums

comments.text:
I thought I had made another comment on this a while back. I basically said 
I'm a liberal because I respect that we are not independent free spirits 
who can auto-magically do whatever we want. The brain is a physical organ 
and changing things takes effort and people working together.

But bashing on people who are clearly in a downspin on casual science 
YouTube videos for their poor grasp of academic philosophy isn't really a 
good way to go about that.
comments.author: Alex Houghstow

comments.text:
+Tyrone Biggums choice does exist because it is not an empirical concept. 
It's a human construct and it's as simple as that. If I killed you, myself, 
and the rest of the human race would the idea or even word of choice exist? 
No. Nothing would "exist" therefore your argument leads to ad absurdum. It 
makes no fucking sense. Also, any Philosophy 101 class will tell you 
fatalism =/= determinism there is a fucking reason why we created two words 
for two different ideas. They're INHERENTLY similar, but APPLICABLY 
different. Go back to school. Determinism and fatalism don't even hold true 
anymore because Quantum Mechanics shits on them. And in philosophy if EVEN 
ONE OTHER IDEA can CONTRADICT the basis of another then that ENTIRE IDEA IS 
WRONG. 

Welcome to academia, good luck next time.
comments.author: Alan “Tekken” David

comments.text:
+Alex Houghstow
Choice doesn't exist. People cannot change things that are impossible to 
change. Conservatives don't understand this, which is why they look down on 
the poor and irreligious.
comments.author: Tyrone Biggums

comments.text:
You're partly right. Fatalism says your choices don't matter, while 
determinism says all your choices can be predicted ahead of time. Not the 
same at all.

The problem with fatalism is that when people think that way they start 
accepting things that they should be trying to change, because the outcome 
is "determined by fate." But we still make the choice not to act. The 
potential for a hypothetical being who knows everything about now and can 
tell everything that comes after doesn't change that. +Tyrone Biggums
comments.author: Alex Houghstow

comments.text:
+Alex Houghstow No you are wrong. Fatalism and determinism are the same 
general idea, and both leave you powerless.
comments.author: Tyrone Biggums

comments.text:
Determinism and fatalism are separate things. Fatalism, where outcomes in 
life don't depend on your decisions, is disempowering. Determinism, where 
the decisions you make are predetermined by your attitude and state of 
knowledge, which in turn are determined by your previous states and what 
happens to you... is weird to think about, but honestly meaningless in the 
end. You still make the choice. Your strength and will are the part of you 
that lets you use different knowledge and feelings to make different 
choices.
comments.author: Alex Houghstow

comments.text:
Well next time please don't sound like "because quantum physics states 
balabala...so determinism is not correct". that's not explaining anything. 
besides, some theories are themselves unfalsifiable so you can't be certain 
what is the ultimate theory.﻿

comments.text:
I hate these kinda videos where the key question is just not explained. you 
just say it is that way, deal with it. for example the key question in this 
video is obviously how you can tell that something has no cause. the rest 
of the video shouldn't be news to anyone. I'm sorry but this video is just 
bullshit. you are simply beating about the bush. I for my part don't see a 
possible way determinism can be disproven. of course it is not possible to 
ever get all information there is due to the uncertaincy principle but that 
doesn't make determinism any less valid. ﻿
comments.author: Digital Freedom

comments.text:
I can think of a way, although not sure if it's actually how they did it. 
Assuming determinism is true, then some how we arrive at a paradox 
(something both being true and false for example). Now unless you're 
willing to deny pure logic instead of determinism, then determinism must be 
false.

Of course this is just how I think it can be done, I'm not sure if that's 
how they did it or not.
comments.author: Khanh Duong Phan

comments.text:
We simply don't have enough information to detemine whether or not we could 
predict everything if we had enough information. this idea collapses in 
itself. it might be true that we can't predict everything but that doesn't 
mean that something greater than human conception couldn't. but then again 
i could be wrong but we don't know nor will we ever be able to know. you 
see where this is going﻿
comments.author: Digital Freedom

comments.text:
You just can't predict everything. You can have exact same circumstances in 
2 experiments, they can be no difference at all, you still can get 2 
different results when dealing with quantum mechanics. The idea of hidden 
parameters that determine the behaviour of particles was disproved both 
theoratically and experimentally through bell's theorem.
comments.author: WaterMelonFan1

comments.text:
Just assuming all things were determined, and further assuming a kind of 
miraculous supercomputer could compute all the details of the future. Then 
this computer could never make the results known to anybody, since then the 
predicted future would be instantly changed. For instance, if you "learn" 
that you will be crossing Bakerstreet at 6:10 p.m., then you can of course 
choose not to go there - if only to make fun of that computer ;-)
comments.author: eltamin1966
